full_text:
The only data the market truly embraces as bullish is benign data‚Äînot too hot, not too cold. Historically, bull markets sustain themselves during moderate, stable economic periods‚Äîwhat we call a Goldilocks Economy.

Strong data ‚Üí signals no rate cuts.
Weak data ‚Üí revives recession fears.
Mild, steady data ‚Üí the ‚Äújust right‚Äù scenario that keeps the market climbing.

In short, the best data for the market is the kind that doesn‚Äôt move the needle too far in either direction. https://t.co/JXzFFTmMtn

But let his death not be in vain. If anything good can come from this, may it be the
full_text:
The tragic murder of Charles Kirk has pushed us further down a dangerous path. It‚Äôs another example of how division, chaos, and media-fueled outrage are tearing at the fabric of our society.

But let his death not be in vain. If anything good can come from this, may it be the outrage that finally acts as a catalyst for change ‚Äî a moment that forces us to demand accountability, reject propaganda, and return to truth.

Because without change, the cycle of violence and fear will only deepen ‚Äî and that‚Äôs a future none of us should accept.

The media has become a vicious cycle of division.

They create conflict, add fuel to the fire, and pit us against each other. Then they sensationalize the chaos ‚Äî the shootings, the killings, the worst of humanity ‚Äî and profit from the ratings and clicks it generates.

This isn‚Äôt journalism; it‚Äôs propaganda. It‚Äôs disgusting. News needs to go back to being news ‚Äî facts, truth, accountability ‚Äî not a machine designed to divide.

And the damage goes deeper: this cycle is eroding our First Amendment freedoms and opportunities for discourse. 

By manufacturing fear and silencing dissent through intimidation, the media makes people afraid to express themselves, afraid to speak truth. That is very, very dangerous ‚Äî because when free speech dies, freedom dies with it.

My heart goes out to Charles Kirk‚Äôs family. I‚Äôm deeply sorry for their loss ‚Äî and ashamed that humanity has digressed to a place where people must fear for their safety simply for voicing an opinion.

This is not freedom. This is not the America our First Amendment was meant to protect. And until we demand better, tragedies like this will continue to silence voices and weaken the very foundation of our liberty

My deepest condolences to the families, friends, and loved ones who were affected. My heartfelt wish is that a tragedy of that magnitude never strikes our https://t.co/H06R6tPCUT
full_text:
On September 11, 2001, I lived and worked in New York City. I can tell you firsthand‚Äîlife there changed forever on that day. My deepest condolences to the families, friends, and loved ones who were affected. My heartfelt wish is that a tragedy of that magnitude never strikes our nation again.  
The image of the towers in flames is horrific‚Äîbut it is also unforgettable. As painful as it is to see, it must be remembered. Only by confronting the reality of that day do we stand a chance of not repeating it.
